deck.name: Small Talk Mastery
deck.description: Learn to talk about yourself, ask natural questions, keep conversations going and use everyday expressions.

cards.definition: informal way to say you're interested in something
cards.context: I'm into photography and hiking.

cards.definition: used to tell someone your home city or country
cards.context: I'm from Paris, but I live in London now.

cards.definition: used to describe where you spent your childhood
cards.context: I grew up in a small village in the south of France.

cards.definition: describes how long you've lived somewhere
cards.context: I've been living here for about three years.

cards.definition: used to describe your professional field
cards.context: I work in marketing for a tech company.

cards.definition: a way to describe your personality traits
cards.context: I'm a morning person — I love waking up early.

cards.definition: used to talk about hobbies and leisure activities
cards.context: In my free time, I like to play guitar.

cards.definition: used to describe where you were born or raised
cards.context: I'm originally from Brazil, but I moved here when I was ten.

cards.definition: expresses a long-held desire or dream
cards.context: I've always wanted to visit Japan.

cards.definition: a dramatic way to say something is very important to you
cards.context: I can't live without my morning coffee.

cards.term: What do you do for fun?
cards.definition: a question about someone's hobbies
cards.context: What do you do for fun? — I usually go cycling.

cards.definition: a natural way to ask about someone's work experience
cards.context: What's your job like? — It's stressful but rewarding.

cards.definition: asking if someone has previously visited a place
cards.context: Have you been here before? — No, it's my first time.

cards.term: How long have you been doing that?
cards.definition: asking how long someone has practiced an activity
cards.context: How long have you been doing yoga? — About two years.

cards.definition: a conversational way to ask why someone is at a place or event
cards.context: What brings you here? — I'm visiting a friend.

cards.definition: asking if someone is local
cards.context: Are you from around here? — No, I'm just visiting.

cards.definition: asking if someone regularly visits a place
cards.context: Do you come here often? — Yeah, I love this café.

cards.definition: asking someone's opinion on a topic
cards.context: What's your take on remote work? — I think it's great.

cards.definition: asking about someone's connection to a person or place
cards.context: How do you know the host? — We work together.

cards.term: What have you been up to?
cards.definition: asking what someone has been doing recently
cards.context: What have you been up to lately? — Not much, just work.

cards.definition: a response showing genuine interest in what someone said
cards.context: I'm learning to play the piano. — That's interesting!

cards.definition: a way to keep a conversation going by showing curiosity
cards.context: I just got back from Tokyo. — Really? Tell me more!

cards.definition: showing that you understand and relate to what someone said
cards.context: Mondays are tough. — I know what you mean.

cards.definition: expressing that you share the same experience or opinion
cards.context: I love Italian food. — Same here!

cards.definition: an exclamation of surprise or disbelief
cards.context: I met a celebrity yesterday. — No way!

cards.definition: used to connect what someone said to a related topic
cards.context: That reminds me of a trip I took last summer.

cards.definition: used to transition to a related topic
cards.context: Speaking of which, have you seen the new restaurant on Main Street?

cards.definition: used to introduce a new but loosely related topic
cards.context: By the way, are you free this weekend?

cards.definition: redirecting the question to the other person
cards.context: I love hiking. What about you?

cards.definition: encouraging someone to continue their story
cards.context: So, what happened next? — Well, we missed the train!

cards.definition: a filler phrase used to check understanding or add emphasis
cards.context: It was, you know, one of those really awkward moments.

cards.definition: used to clarify or rephrase something
cards.context: I like it, I mean, it's not perfect but it's good.

cards.definition: used to express a sincere or frank opinion
cards.context: To be honest, I didn't enjoy the movie that much.

cards.definition: used to soften a statement or mean 'somewhat'
cards.context: I'm kind of tired. Can we leave soon?

cards.definition: means the answer changes based on the situation
cards.context: Do you prefer tea or coffee? — It depends on my mood.

cards.definition: used to express a tentative opinion or agreement
cards.context: I guess we could try that new place.

cards.definition: used to accept someone's point even if you slightly disagree
cards.context: I don't like sushi. — Fair enough, not everyone does.

cards.definition: used to show you understand and agree with a point
cards.context: I took the bus because it was raining. — That makes sense.

cards.definition: an informal way to say 'it's okay' or 'you're welcome'
cards.context: Sorry I'm late! — No worries, we just got here.

cards.definition: an expression of approval for someone's achievement or decision
cards.context: I started going to the gym. — Good for you!

cards.definition: used to share an uncertain opinion politely
cards.context: I'm not sure, but I think the shop closes at six.

cards.definition: a strong way to say 'yes' or express total agreement
cards.context: Do you want to come? — Absolutely!

cards.definition: used to confirm that someone has expressed your thought perfectly
cards.context: So it's like a mix of comedy and drama? — Exactly!

cards.definition: a soft way to say 'no'
cards.context: Did you like the film? — Not really, it was too long.

cards.definition: informal way to agree with a plan or suggestion
cards.context: Let's meet at noon. — Sounds good!

cards.definition: letting the other person decide
cards.context: Pizza or sushi? — It's up to you, I'm fine with both.

cards.definition: expressing very strong agreement
cards.context: This movie is a masterpiece. — I couldn't agree more.

cards.definition: acknowledging that someone made a valid argument
cards.context: We should leave early to avoid traffic. — That's a good point.

cards.definition: a polite way to delay deciding
cards.context: Do you want to join us? — Let me think about it.

cards.definition: promising to respond later
cards.context: I'll get back to you once I check my schedule.

cards.term: It was nice talking to you
cards.definition: a polite way to end a conversation
cards.context: I've got to go. It was nice talking to you!

cards.definition: expressing the desire to stay connected
cards.context: Let's keep in touch! Here's my number.

cards.definition: a friendly farewell for Friday or Saturday
cards.context: See you next week. Have a great weekend!

cards.definition: politely announcing you need to leave
cards.context: It's getting late, I'd better get going.

cards.definition: a warm way to say goodbye after a first meeting
cards.context: It was lovely meeting you. I hope we'll see each other again!

cards.definition: light, casual conversation about unimportant topics
cards.context: British people are great at small talk about the weather.

cards.definition: to do or say something to ease tension at the start of a conversation
cards.context: He told a joke to break the ice at the party.

cards.definition: an uncomfortable pause in a conversation
cards.context: There was an awkward silence after his comment.

cards.definition: to get along well with someone immediately
cards.context: We hit it off from the very first conversation.

cards.definition: to exchange news with someone you haven't seen in a while
cards.context: Let's grab coffee and catch up sometime.

cards.definition: informal conversation about trivial topics
cards.context: We had some chit-chat before the meeting started.

cards.definition: to have a friendly relationship with someone
cards.context: I get along with most of my colleagues.

cards.term: It's on the tip of my tongue
cards.definition: when you almost remember something but can't quite recall it
cards.context: What's that actor's name? It's on the tip of my tongue.

cards.definition: something sounds familiar
cards.context: Her name rings a bell — I think we've met before.

cards.definition: to start talking about something different
cards.context: She quickly changed the subject when politics came up.

cards.definition: used to return to the main point or wrap up a topic
cards.context: Anyway, what I was trying to say is that we should leave early.

cards.definition: indicating you understand someone's perspective
cards.context: I see your point, but I still think we should try.

cards.definition: used to share information you believe to be true
cards.context: As far as I know, the meeting is still on for Thursday.

cards.definition: a phrase introducing a personal point of view
cards.context: In my opinion, learning a language takes daily practice.

cards.definition: a casual way to give an estimate or opinion
cards.context: How far is it? — I'd say about 20 minutes by car.
